Honey Pie, you are making me crazy
 I’m in love, but I’m lazy
 So won’t you please come home
These song lyrics are similar to 20s-40s jazz songs. Paul Mccartney said the song was inspired by his father who was in a jazz band. Another inspiration was the Billy Cotton Show Band.
Now she’s hit the big time in the U.S.A.​

The vocals of this line are compressed and a phonograph sound is dubbed over the lyrics to make it sound like an old record of the music hall or vaudeville era—back when “the big time” had (even more of) an elusive, magical quality.

You became a legend of the silver screen
 And now the thought of meeting you
 Makes me weak in the knee
The “silver screen” is the cinema – she’s a film star! Now he’s very nervous about meeting his former lover.
She was a working girl North of England way

“Working girl” is an archaic euphemism for “prostitute”. The song can be interpreted much more innocently without knowledge of this. If she was just a girl who worked and became a superstar, the song would be much more fitting of its upbeat tune. It’s not nearly that innocent though – it’s actually laced with innuendo.
